title: Letters to the editor Sunday
text:
Since the people that visit Bonaventure Cemetery get so much enjoyment out of seeing Buddy the Fox: Instead of getting rid of him, why not give him rabies shots and let him stay?
I will be more than glad to pay for them.
P.S. There are a lot more than one fox in the area.
JIM WOOTEN
Savannah
Who would want to work for a corrupt police department?
Let me start by saying I have nothing against City Manager Stephanie Cutter.
I do not feel that she is qualified to oversee the police department, so I offer a solution.
I hear and read all the time that the new police chief’s hands, like maybe other chiefs’ hands, were tied by the city manager.
How about a police commissioner who will oversee the police department?
This works in all the major cities.
Let this person be chosen by a group of the mayor, district attorney, chairman of the Chatham County Commission, sheriff and maybe an independent citizen. I have never met Chief Joseph Lumpkin, but I feel safe in saying he did not need this job, but took it anyway as a challenge.
How can he do his job when his hands are tied?
With the recent lawsuit, it seems possible that some of those that served under Willie Lovett may still be on the force and the perception in the public eye is that our police force is still corrupt, which will explain all the crime and not use the lack of officers as an excuse.
To close, who in their right mind would want to work for a police department with all these dark clouds over their heads?
CHIP DETWILER
Savannah
How to improve Savannah’s tour guides
Savannah is a city of character, not a city of characters.
The feeling of the Hostess City cannot be summed up by a bench, a statue, a “hey y’all,” or even a Panama hat.
Notable personalities have helped preserve its character; citizens like Thomas Gamble, Lee Adler, Sarah Parsons and W. W. Law (just to name a few) have saved this jewel of city planning for generations to come.
As National Trust Guide to Savannah Rhoulac Toledano claims, “A viable historic city is the best gift a community can give to itself and to civilization.”
Historic Jonesborough, Tenn., is the Storytelling Capital of the World, and as such, storytellers and their listeners gather there from all across America to share stories.
Savannah is the original capital of the British Colony of Georgia and people from all over the world come to learn its history.
“A narrative that is not merely in a dry detail of events, but a series of authentic historical facts, determined with acuteness, commented on with deliberation, and relieved by pleasing anecdote or interesting episode.” (William of Malmesbury)
A tour guide accreditation system needs to be established.
This could possibly be accomplished under the auspices of Historic Savannah Foundation that could work with Armstrong State University to offer a course(s) that culminates in a certificate of completion.
There are many precedents for granting licenses and permits to tour guides.
The U.K. has a four-badge system, which reserves the Blue Badge for the most competent and accurate guides.
France grants a “license professionelle guide conferencier” — a university level diploma. In Italy, where tourism is one of the leading industries, tour guides are held to a high standard to ensure that consumers are protected and that they receive the highest level of service.
For example, after earning a degree in art history, the applicant is required to pass an intensive exam issued by the province in which he or she wishes to work.
You can easily spot a licensed guide by the credentials they wear around their neck or carry on their person.
I am by no means insisting on a college-level diploma, but merely that guides demonstrate a basic knowledge of the facts so that the visitor is not shortchanged.
The National Park Service has a buzzword: “infotainment.” People want entertainment, but they also want good, reliable information. Seeing a badge of accreditation will help tourists know whom to choose as their guide.
ROBERT EDGERLY
Savannah
Don’t be a Kool-Aid drinker
I am writing in response to the letter of Oct. 4 from Emma Walthour Morel Adler entitled, “Pope Francis reminds her of Martin Luther.”
Luther was a reformer, but one must be reminded he was just a man.
He, like most men, had a side that people try to hide. He was anti-Semitic.
At first, he was sympathetic to the Jews for their opposition to the Catholic Church, but when he realized they would not convert to Christianity he turned violently against them.
Emma should read Luther’s “The Jews and their Lies.” He advocates setting fire to their schools and synagogues; their houses be razed and destroyed; all their prayer books and Talmudic writings be taken from them; all their cash and treasure be taken from them and put aside for safekeeping.
Read his entire essay to really understand Luther’s hatred of the Jews.
Hitler used the writings of Luther to justify the Holocaust.
As to Pope Francis, doing what “he thinks is best for all humanity,” let me say this: Throughout history many have done what they thought was best for humanity. Tyrants such as Lenin, Mao, Mussolini, Stalin, Ivan the Terrible, Pinochet, Pol Pot and Kim Jong Il are just a few. I am not comparing the pope to them, just illustrating how it can be abused.
One must be weary of anyone professing to know what is best. Do as Paul writes in Acts 17;11. He praised the Bereans because they examined the Scriptures every day to see if what Paul said was true.
Do not be a Kool-Aid drinker.
AL SAPP
Savannah
